data.title: Marius (name) - Wikipedia
data.snippet:
Male given name and surname

Marius

| Bust general Gaius Marius. He was the most prominent member of the gens Maria bearing name Marius. |
| Pronunciation | Classical Latin: (/wiki/Help:IPA/Latin "Help:IPA/Latin") |
| Gender | Male |
| Language | Latin |
| Origin |
| Region of origin | Roman Empire |
| Other names |
| Alternative spelling | Marivs |
| Variant forms | Mario "Mario (given name)"), Mário "Mario (given name)"), Marios, Mariusz, Marian "Marian (given name)") |
| Derived | Mars "Mars (mythology)"), mas, or mar |

Marius is a male name, a Roman family name, and a modern given name. [...] The name Marius was used by members of the Roman gens Maria. It is thought to be derived from either[citation needed] the Roman war god Mars "Mars (mythology)") or from the Latin root mas or maris meaning "male". It may also derive from the Latin word mare meaning "sea", the plural of which is maria.

In Christian times, it was syncretized as a masculine form of the unrelated feminine given name Maria "Maria (given name)"), from the Hebrew Miriam "Miriam (given name)"), Aramaic variant Mariam "Mariam (disambiguation)"), and used alongside it.

Today, the name Marius is a common given name in Romania, Norway, and Lithuania. The name is also used in the Philippines, France, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, and South Africa. [...] Marius, a character in the book The Letter for the King
 Marius, a non-playable Mii opponent in the Wii "Wii (video game series)") series
 Marius of Britain, legendary king of the Britons during the Roman occupation
 Marius Pontmercy, in Victor Hugo's novel Les Misérables
 Marius, protagonist of the novel Marius the Epicurean by Walter Pater
 Marius Von Hagen, one of the four male leads in the otome game Tears of Themis
 Marius Titus, the playable protagonist in the video game Ryse: Son of Rome

# Marius

## 1. Marius name meaning and origin

Marius is a masculine given name of Roman origin, derived from the Latin name 'Marius,' which was a Roman family name associated with the Latin word 'mas' or 'maris,' meaning 'male' or 'masculine.' The name gained prominence through Gaius Marius (157-86 BCE), a renowned Roman general and statesman who was elected consul an unprecedented seven times and implemented significant military reforms that transformed the Roman army. [...] Marius is a masculine name with ancient Roman origins, derived from the Roman family name Marius and ultimately connected to Mars, the Roman god of war. While the name enjoys moderate popularity in several European countries, particularly in Scandinavia, Romania, and France, it appears to be uncommon in both the United States and the United Kingdom.

Despite its classical heritage and strong historical connections—notably to Gaius Marius, a famous Roman general—the name hasn't achieved widespread usage in English-speaking countries. Marius remains a distinctive choice that combines historical gravitas with a certain continental sophistication, giving it appeal for parents seeking a name with both strength and literary associations.

## 3. Variations and nicknames of Marius [...] The name Marius, with its ancient Roman origins, has evolved across numerous cultures and languages while maintaining its dignified character. In its original Latin form, Marius was a Roman family name believed to be derived from Mars, the god of war, lending it a strong, masculine quality. As the name traveled across Europe, it developed distinct variants in various languages. In French, it remains Marius, pronounced with a characteristic Gallic flair, while German-speaking regions often use Marius or sometimes Mario. In Nordic countries, the spelling Marius prevails, though occasionally appears as Mårius in some regions. Italian and Spanish cultures transformed it into Mario, while Eastern European languages offer versions like Mariusz (Polish) and Márius (Hungarian). The Lithuanian

# Marius

Gender Masculine

Usage Ancient Roman, Romanian, German, Dutch, Norwegian, Danish, French, Lithuanian

Pronounced Pron. /ˈma.ri.us/(Latin)
 /ˈmɛɹ.i.əs/(English)
 /ˈmæɹ.i.əs/(English)
 /ˈma.rjus/(Romanian)
 /ˈmaː.ʁi.ʊs/(German)
 /ˈmaː.ri.ʏs/(Dutch)
 /ma.ʁjys/(French)
  [key·simplify]

## Meaning & History

Roman family name that was derived either from Mars, the name of the Roman god of War, or else from the Latin root mas, maris meaning "male". Gaius Marius was a famous Roman consul of the 2nd century BC. Since the start of the Christian era, it has occasionally been used as a masculine form of Maria.

## Related Names

VariantsMario(German) Marijus(Lithuanian) [...] VariantsMario(German) Marijus(Lithuanian)

User SubmissionsMárius, Màrius, Maríus, Mariüs

data.title: Gaius Marius - Wikipedia
data.snippet:
many of the problems he faced during his early career in Rome show the difficulties that faced a "new man" (novus homo) in being accepted into the stratified upper echelons of Roman society, Marius – even as a young man – was not poor or even middle-class; he was most assuredly born into inherited wealth, gained most likely from large land holdings. In fact, his family's resources were definitely large enough to support not just one member of the family in Roman politics, but two: Marius's younger brother, Marcus Marius "Marcus Marius (praetor 102 BC)"), also entered Roman public life. [...] After fifteen days of thanksgiving, Catulus and Marius celebrated a joint triumph. Plutarch reports that Marius was also hailed as "the third founder of Rome", but this is unlikely, as the identification of Camillus as a second founder dates to after the Sullan-era annalists and may be in fact post-Ciceronean. In the popular imagination, it was Marius who "deserved to be the sole beneficiary of the two triumphs awarded for the decisive conclusion of the war". At the same time, Marius's consular colleague, Manius Aquillius, defeated the Sicilian slave revolt in the Second Servile War. Having saved the Republic from destruction and at the height of his political powers, Marius desired another consulship to secure land grants for his veteran volunteers and to ensure he received appropriate [...] ## Legacy

[edit]

Marius was an extremely successful Roman general and politician. In ancient sources, he has been repeatedly characterised as having unending ambition and opportunism. Plutarch says of him:

> if Marius could have been persuaded to sacrifice to the Greek Muses and Graces, he would not have put the ugliest possible crown upon a most illustrious career in field and forum, nor have been driven by the blasts of passion, ill-timed ambition, and insatiable greed upon the shore of a most cruel and savage old age.

data.title: Marius de Romanus | The Vampire Chronicles Wiki | Fandom
data.snippet:
Marius has a conflicted attitude towards religion and spirituality, as he is the keeper of the shrine of Those Who Must Be Kept. Marius does not believe in divine power, and blames religious ideas for his own unwilling transformation into a vampire, which often brings him into conflict with other vampires as Christianity and the Children of Satan emerge in Europe. His lover Pandora accuses him of having "made a religion out of reason."

## Biography[]

### Early Life[]

Marius was a citizen of the Roman Gallic city of Massilia, born in approximately 30 BCE. He was the illegitimate child of a Keltoi woman from the land of Gaul and a wealthy Roman. [...] Marius was a scholar and chronicler by the age of twenty, traveling quite a lot and visiting all the great European cities. When he is twenty-five, he meets a ten year old girl named Lydia at the home of her father, a Roman senator, and is impressed by her interest in poetry. Marius asks to become betrothed to Lydia, with the intention that it will delay his own obligation to get married until she is of marriageable age. He is denied by her father, who explains to Lydia that this is the reason he was rejected. Lydia encounters Marius once more at a religious festival when she is fifteen, and informs him that she asked her father to allow them to get married, but was denied again due to Marius's lower social status. [...] ## Personality[]

Marius is an exceptionally sagacious, wise and optimistic vampire. He loves to read and to write, and sees himself as a historian and a continual observer of the history of the human race. Marius's interests include all manner of intellectual and artistic pursuits, including filmmaking, writing, and most notably, painting. Marius is obsessed with the art created by humans, but is distraught by his inability to create art that is not somewhat unnatural due to his vampiric nature. Marius is frequently torn between his desire to live among humans and the limitations of his ability to do so. Despite his age, he prefers to move and act like a human in situations where he could otherwise use his vampiric powers.
